questions.title: Question 1 for Class 191007
questions.main: Why do most hurricanes move westward over tropical waters?
questions.answer: The form between the equator and 30 degrees  latitude in the trade winds which generally blow from the east.

questions.title: Question 2 for Class 191007
questions.main: Describe how the general circulation helps to explain zones of abundant and sparse precipitation along a line that runs from the equator to the poles.
questions.answer: The Hadley cell results from rising air at the equator that sinks at around 30 degrees  latitude.  Rising air causes clouds and precipitation while sinking air reduces cloud cover so 30 degrees  ends to be the latitude where many deserts are found.  Air moving poleward from 30 degrees  runs into air flowing from the poles at around 50 degrees  and is forced upward along the polar front maing this a relatively wet region.  The poles tend to be regions of subsidence and tend to be much drier.

questions.title: Question 3 for Class 191007
questions.main: The winds aloft in the middle latitudes would not blow from the west if:
questions.answer: C) the air over high latitudes became warmer than over the equator

mcq.option: A) the earth's rotation slowed or increased slightly
B) the tilt of the earth changed slightly
C) the air over high latitudes became warmer than over the equator
D) the direction of the moon's orbit around the earth were reversed

questions.title: Question 4 for Class 191007
questions.main: Which latitude belt best describes the middle latitudes?

questions.title: Question 5 for Class 191007
questions.main: The world's deserts are found at 30 degrees  latitude because:
questions.answer: D) of the sinking air of the subtropical highs

mcq.option: A) the intertropical convergence zone is located there
B) of the sinking air of the polar front
C) of the convergence of the prevailing westerlies and the Northeast Trades
D) of the sinking air of the subtropical highs
E) of the doldrums

questions.title: Question 6 for Class 191007
questions.main: In terms of the three-cell general circulation model the driest regions of the earth should be near:
questions.answer: E) 30¬∞ latitude and the polar regions

mcq.option: A) the equator and the polar regions
B) the equator and 30¬∞ latitude
C) the equator and 60¬∞ latitude
D) 30¬∞ latitude and 60¬∞ latitude
E) 30¬∞ latitude and the polar regions

questions.title: Question 7 for Class 191007
questions.main: Which of the following helps to explain why even though northern latitudes experience 24 hours of sunlight on June 22 they are not warmer than latitudes further south?

mcq.option: A) solar energy is spread over a larger area in northern latitudes
B) some of the sun's energy is reflected by snow and ice in the northern latitudes
C) increased cloud cover reflects solar energy in the northern latitudes
D) solar energy is used to melt frozen soil in the northern latitudes
E) all of the above

questions.title: Question 8 for Class 191007
questions.main: Explain why even though the polar jet stream coincides with the polar front some surface regions are more favorable for the development of mid-latitude cyclones than others.
questions.answer: Jet streaks along the polar front jet stream provide areas of strong convergence and divergence.

questions.title: Question 9 for Class 191007
questions.main: Why do upper-level winds in the middle latitudes of both hemispheres generally blow from the west?
questions.answer: Because winds at these altitudes are approximately geostrophic with higher pressures (warmer temperatures) to the south and lower pressures (colder temperatures) to the north.

questions.title: Question 10 for Class 191007
questions.answer: A) the direction from which the wind is blowing

mcq.option: A) the direction from which the wind is blowing
B) the direction to which the wind is blowing
C) always directly from high toward low pressure
D) always directly from low toward high pressure
